- if you start sharding, it's a pretty natural model to follow, you just have to give up  calls atomicity.
- if you wan return values, you have to make explicit callbacks, CPS style

This should feel familiar, @marksammiller helped me think through this ;)

1090027415542194177.text:
A contracts returns two things
1. The new value for its storage
2. A list of operations.

The list of operations is added to a FIFO queue (not a stack). They are consumed and executed one by one.

You have a guarantee of atomicity for the execution of the entire thing.

1030629664543440901.text: The physical world and the online world have *really* different moral properties when it comes to claiming "territory" and enforcing rules, all based on the fact that the online world is a multi-dimensional, entirely created space.

1030628893332525057.text: Online, someone else's interactions don't necessarily affect you - you can potentially put up as many walls or bridges of code as you wish (interestingly, software rarely allows the user to do this, and muting/blocking and search are primitive solutions to this)

1030627621808336896.text: Online, you're creating a new space for your community, from scratch. Online communities are positive sum; there's endless potential for new ones, and you're only limited by people's time and attention.

1030625990362505217.text: This is wrong for two reasons: the physical world has windfall resources that no one has a clear moral right to and in the physical world, trying to interact with someone usually means that others are affected somehow. 993514822028296199.text: 6b) But, if the government can credibly commit to not do the expensive reengineering, the individuals lose this power and are incentivized not to build in the flood plain.pic.twitter.com/otKRYerUTw

993513979682041856.text: 6a) Kyland and Prescott provide another example: government flood policy. If individuals build houses in a flood plain, they can force the government to reengineer the flood control measures to accommodate them, even if that's worse than them not building.

993513250024112130.text: 5) Why does this matter? Bad things happen when you can't make credible commitments. The prisoner's dilemma is a common examplepic.twitter.com/OiTDmdtzhh

993512172213825538.text: 4) Shepsle differentiates between two types of credibility- motivational and imperative. In motivational credibility, you're going to keep your promise because you want to; in imperative, because you are forced to.pic.twitter.com/Ge7xNGIzIk

993511151005720576.text: 3) Making a credible commitment often involves disabling discretion - i.e. taking the possibility of reneging out of your hands.

993510646342864896.text: 2) The problem of commitment can arise in self-management (a focus of Schelling's), between individuals (contract), and between individuals and governments (policy-making).pic.twitter.com/8ve7oNTztL
